text: So currently at the end of my show reel, is the only real python tool i've properly made so my python/coding skills is the area I need to improve the most with. I was wondering as a rigger do you use code while you rig, if so how much of it makes up your rigging process and what kind of tools are good to make for rigging?

Yes, coding skills be they python or melscript, are very helpful for rigging and games production in general. One of the most important tools I rely on are auto rigging tools, because building a rig from scratch every time I need to rig something is my worst nightmare. I started out as a plain and simple animator so my coding skills are quite light at the moment, but as you try to achieve more and more ambitious things in a game, automating the process via code becomes essential. From simple exporting tools to animation retargeting tools, it allows you to automate processes that would eat up a lot of time if you always had to carry it out manually.

It's great for any sort of auto rigging tools of course, but I'd also suggest thinking about scripts for making animation tasks easier, such as physics simulations tools like Overlapper or Physics Tools for Maya. These are the kind of things which become really helpful to speed up the animation process.

However theres also things like, animation retargeting tools. A good example is the facial animation transferring tool that Jeremy Ernst talks about in this GDC talk: <https://www.gdcvault.com/play/1014366/Fast-and-Efficient-Facial-Rigging>
It's incredibly common to try to prevent the repetition of any task within the process of production, and in this talk he breaks down a facial rigging system he came up with that allows the transfer of facial animation via a intermediary geometry mask to transfer animation between characters with vastly varied faces. Stuff like this was used in the most recent God of War too (which you can see here) and is only possible through smart planning and clever scripts.

I find the best way to find out what kind of things I should be learning about are by looking at the portfolio of people who are creating cool games. Heres a few examples I still find useful.

<https://vimeo.com/214084286> - Nick Rogers

<https://gumroad.com/graphite9> - Brian Horgan

<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zvUfiKQI5jQ> - Mateusz Poplawski

<https://vimeo.com/152871940> - Lucy Webber

It's a tough area to navigate but it's very very valuable skill to have.
